page.title: International public opinion on the war in Afghanistan

revision.comment: Made minor changes to remove unnecessary rhetoric and typos.
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{POV|date=February 2012}} {{cleanup|date=February 2012}} }}
<!--this is a mere list of data--> A 47-nation global survey of public opinion conducted in June 2007 by the [[Pew Global Attitudes Project]] found considerable opposition to the NATO military operations in Afghanistan. In 2 out of the 47 countries was there a majority that favoured keeping troops in Afghanistan – Israel (59%) and Kenya (60%).<ref name="47-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey p.24, p.116">[http://pewglobal.org/reports/pdf/256.pdf 47-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey p.24, p.116]</ref> On the other hand, in 41 of the 47 countries pluralities wanted NATO troops out of Afghanistan as soon as possible.<ref name="47-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey p.24, p.116"/> In 32 out of 47 countries majorities wanted NATO troops out of Afghanistan as soon as possible. Majorities in 7 out of 12 NATO member countries wanted troops withdrawn as soon as possible.<ref name="47-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey p.24, p.116"/><ref name="Global Unease With Major World Powers">{{cite web|url=http://pewglobal.org/reports/display.php?ReportID=256|title=Global Unease With Major World Powers|date=27 June 2007|work=Pew Research Center's Global Attitudes Project|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="Afghan war not worth it, say most Americans">{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/politics/afghan-war-not-worth-it-say-most-americans-20101217-190pq.html|title=Afghanistan war not worth it, say most Americans|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
The 24-nation Pew Global Attitudes survey in June 2008 again found that majorities or pluralities in 21 of 24 countries wanted NATO troops removed from Afghanistan as soon as possible. In 3 out of the 24 countries – the U.S. (50%), Australia (60%), and Britain (48%) – public opinion favoured keeping troops there until the situation stabilized.<ref name="24-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Project Survey">{{cite web|url=http://pewglobal.org/reports/display.php?ReportID=260|title=Global Economic Gloom – China and India Notable Exceptions|date=12 June 2008|work=Pew Research Center's Global Attitudes Project|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="24-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Project Survey"/> Since then, public opinion in Australia and Britain has shifted, and the majority of Australians and British now also want their troops to be brought home from Afghanistan.<ref name="Britons call for troop withdrawal">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/7725228.stm|title=BBC NEWS - UK - Britons call for troop withdrawal|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=BBC News|date=13 November 2008}}</ref><ref name="Australians lose faith in Afghan war effort">{{cite web|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/news/local/news/general/australians-lose-faith-in-afghan-war-effort/1320931.aspx |title=Australians lose faith in Afghan war effort |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081003032403/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/news/local/news/general/australians-lose-faith-in-afghan-war-effort/1320931.aspx |archivedate=October 3, 2008 }}</ref><ref name="Cruel human toll of fight to win Afghan peace">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jul/12/afghanistan-taliban-troops-roadside-bombs|title=This page has been removed - News - The Guardian|work=the Guardian|accessdate=6 February 2015|location=London|first=Jason|last=Burke|date=11 July 2009}}</ref><ref name="Poll finds 51% oppose role in Afghanistan">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/poll-finds-51-oppose-role-in-afghanistan-20090329-9fk5.html|title=Poll finds 51% oppose role in Afghanistan|work=The Age|accessdate=6 February 2015|location=Melbourne}}</ref> Of the seven NATO countries in the survey, not one showed a majority in favor of keeping NATO troops in Afghanistan – one, the U.S., came close to a majority (50%). Of the other six NATO countries, five had majorities of their population wanting NATO troops removed from Afghanistan as soon as possible.<ref name="24-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Project Survey"/>
The 25-nation Pew Global Attitudes survey in June 2009 continued to find that the war in Afghanistan was unpopular in most nations<ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.22 Opposition to War in Afghanistan">[http://www.pewglobal.org/reports/pdf/264.pdf 25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.22 (PDF p.26) Opposition to War in Afghanistan]</ref> and that most publics want American and NATO troops out of Afghanistan.<ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.13 Views of the U.S. and American Foreign policy">[http://www.pewglobal.org/reports/pdf/264.pdf 25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.13 (PDF p.17)]</ref> The 2009 global survey reported that majorities or pluralities in 18 out of 25 countries wanted NATO to remove their troops from Afghanistan as soon as possible.<ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.22 Opposition to War in Afghanistan"/> (Changes from 2008 included Tanzania, South Africa, and Australia having been replaced by Israel, Kenya, the Palestinian Territories, and Canada in the survey, and shifts in opinions in India and Nigeria.) In 4 out of 25 countries was there a majority that favoured keeping NATO troops in Afghanistan – the U.S. (57%), Israel (59%), Kenya (56%), and Nigeria (52%).<ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.22 Opposition to War in Afghanistan"/> Despite American calls for NATO allies to send more troops to Afghanistan, there was majority or plurality opposition to such action in every one of the NATO countries surveyed: Germany (63% opposition), France (62%), Poland (57%), Canada (55%), Britain (51%), Spain (50%), and Turkey (49%).<ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.39 (PDF p.43)">[http://www.pewglobal.org/reports/pdf/264.pdf 25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.39 (PDF p.43)]</ref>
In Europe, polls in France, Germany, Britain, and other countries showed that the European public wanted their troops to be pulled out and less money spent on the war in Afghanistan.<ref name="Cruel human toll of fight to win Afghan peace"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1888764,00.html|title=Obama's Unlikely Ally: Iran Signs On To Afghan Plan|date=31 March 2009|work=TIME.com|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://money.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=798995 Afghan war exposes flaws in assumption of Nato unity] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706110613/http://money.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=798995 |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref><ref name="Europe opposes more troops for Afghanistan: poll">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/topNews/idUSTRE50J0NQ20090120|title=Europe opposes more troops for Afghanistan: poll|work=Reuters|accessdate=6 February 2015|first=Adrian|last=Croft|date=20 January 2009}}</ref>
==International public opinion compared to American public opinion== In October 2001, a poll by CNN/Gallup/USA Today indicated that about 88% of Americans backed military action in Afghanistan, and a poll by Market Opinion Research indicated that about 65% of Britons supported having British troops involved.<ref name="AEI">{{cite web|url=http://www.aei.org/paper/politics-and-public-opinion/polls/america-and-the-war-on-terror-paper/ |title=America and the War on Terror |accessdate=2007-09-27 |publisher=AEI Public Opinion Study |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714221741/http://www.aei.org/paper/politics-and-public-opinion/polls/america-and-the-war-on-terror-paper/ |archivedate=July 14, 2014 }} Published July 24, 2008.</ref> On the other hand, a large-scale 37-nation poll of world opinion carried out by [[Gallup poll|Gallup]] International in late September 2001, found that majorities in most countries favoured a legal response, in the form of extradition and trial, over a military response to 9/11: In 3 of the 37 countries surveyed – the United States, Israel, and India – did majorities favour military action. In 34 out of the 37 countries surveyed, the survey found majorities that did not favour military action: in the United Kingdom (75%), France (67%), Switzerland (87%), Czech Republic (64%), Lithuania (83%), Panama (80%), Mexico (94%), etc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpolicy.org/empire/media/2001/1121opinion.htm|title=World Opinion Opposes the Attack on Afghanistan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comw.org/pda/0201strangevic.html|title=Strange Victory: A critical appraisal of Operation Enduring Freedom and the Afghanistan war}}</ref>
This dichotomy between American and international public opinion on the military operations continues to be seen, although opposition to the war is [[#Growing American opposition to the war|growing in the U.S. as well]]. A Gallup poll conducted July 10–12, 2009 reported that the majority 61% of Americans do not think the U.S. made a mistake in sending military forces in 2001, while 36% of Americans do. 54% also thought things are going well for the U.S..<!-- Gallup Poll, July 10–12, 2009--><ref name="Americans Upbeat on Progress in Iraq, Afghanistan">{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/121727/americans-upbeat-progress-iraq-afghanistan.aspx|title=Americans Upbeat on Progress in Iraq, Afghanistan|author=Gallup, Inc.|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref> An Angus Reid poll conducted July 15–18, 2009, found that 55% of Americans support the military operation, while 35% oppose it. 49% of Americans thought their country did the right thing in sending military forces. About half, 48%, of Americans felt that they did not have a clear idea of what the war is about.<!-- Angus Reid poll July 15–18, 2009 --><ref name="Britain, Canada Differ from U.S. on Afghan War">[http://www.angus-reid.com/polls/view/33849/britain_canada_differ_from_us_on_afghan_war/ Britain, Canada Differ from U.S. on Afghan War] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090724000201/http://www.angus-reid.com/polls/view/33849/britain_canada_differ_from_us_on_afghan_war/ |date=July 24, 2009 }}</ref>
Outside the United States international public opinion has been largely opposed to the war. In a 47-nation June 2007 survey of global public opinion, the [[Pew Global Attitudes Project]] found considerable opposition to NATO operations. In 4 out of the 47 countries surveyed was there a majority that favoured keeping troops: the U.S. (50%), Israel (59%), Ghana (50%), and Kenya (60%).<ref name="47-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey p.24, p.116"/> In 41 of the 47 countries, pluralities want NATO troops out as soon as possible.<ref name="47-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey p.24, p.116"/> In 32 out of 47 countries, majorities want NATO troops out as soon as possible. Majorities in 7 out of 12 NATO member countries say troops should be withdrawn as soon as possible.<ref name="47-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey p.24, p.116"/><ref name="Global Unease With Major World Powers"/>
The 24-nation [[Pew Global Attitudes Project|Pew Global Attitudes]] survey in June 2008 similarly found that majorities or pluralities in 21 of 24 countries want NATO to remove their troops as soon as possible. In 3 out of the 24 countries – the U.S. (50%), Australia (60%), and Britain (48%) – did public opinion lean more toward keeping troops there until the situation has stabilized.<ref name="24-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Project Survey"/><ref name="24-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Project Survey"/> Since that poll, views in Britain and Australia have also diverged from public opinion in the United States, and majorities in both Britain and Australia now want their troops to be brought back home from the war.<ref name="Britons call for troop withdrawal"/><ref name="Australians lose faith in Afghan war effort"/> Of the seven NATO countries included in the survey, none showed a majority in favor of keeping NATO troops until the situation stabilised – only the United States came close to a majority (50%). Of the other six NATO countries, five had majorities of their population wanting NATO troops to be removed as soon as possible: Spain (56%), France (54%), Germany (54%), Poland (65%), and Turkey (72%).<ref name="24-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Project Survey"/>
The 25-nation [[Pew Global Attitudes Project|Pew Global Attitudes]] survey in June 2009 continued to find the war to be unpopular in most nations,<ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.22 Opposition to War in Afghanistan"/> with most publics wanting American and NATO troops out as soon as possible.<ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.13 Views of the U.S. and American Foreign policy"/> The 2009 global survey reported that majorities or pluralities in 18 out of 25 countries want NATO to remove their troops from Afghanistan as soon as possible.<ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.22 Opposition to War in Afghanistan"/> (Changes from the 2008 survey included Tanzania, South Africa, and Australia having been replaced by Israel, Kenya, the Palestinian Territories, and Canada in the survey, as well as shifts in opinions in India and Nigeria.) In 4 out of 25 countries was there a majority that favoured keeping NATO troops in Afghanistan – the U.S. (57%), Israel (59%), Kenya (56%), and Nigeria (52%).<ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.22 Opposition to War in Afghanistan"/> In 1 of the 8 NATO countries included in the survey – the U.S. – was there a majority in favour of keeping NATO troops until the situation stabilised. Despite repeated American calls for NATO allies to send more troops to Afghanistan, there was majority or plurality opposition to such action in all seven of the other NATO countries surveyed: Germany (63% disapprove), France (62%), Poland (57%), Canada (55%), Britain (51%), Spain (50%), and Turkey (49%).<ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.39 (PDF p.43)"/>
The 22-nation [[Pew Global Attitudes Project|Pew Global Attitudes]] survey released in June 2010 again continued to find the war unpopular in most nations. The poll reported that majorities or pluralities in 16 of 22 countries want the military forces to be withdrawn "as soon as possible". One country out of the 22 was there a majority that supported keeping troops until the situation stabilizes (57% in Kenya).<ref name="Pew2010">{{cite web|url=http://pewglobal.org/2010/06/17/obama-more-popular-abroad-than-at-home/2/#chapter-1-views-of-the-u-s-and-american-foreign-policy|title=Obama More Popular Abroad Than At Home, Global Image of U.S. Continues to Benefit|date=17 June 2010|work=Pew Research Center's Global Attitudes Project|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
== United States == ===Growing opposition to the war=== While support for the war continues to be strongest in the U.S. and Israel,<ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.22 Opposition to War in Afghanistan"/><ref name="Global Citizens More Cautious About Afghan War">[http://www.angus-reid.com/analysis/view/33953/global_citizens_more_cautious_about_afghan_war Global Citizens More Cautious About Afghan War] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100428015443/http://www.angus-reid.com/analysis/view/33953/global_citizens_more_cautious_about_afghan_war |date=April 28, 2010 }}</ref> recent polls have also shown growing opposition in the U.S., including majority opposition.<ref>[http://www.miamiherald.com/opinion/other-views/story/1187263.html We can't fight our way out of Afghanistan] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><!--<ref name="Majority in US oppose both wars"/><ref name="Poll details: Majority in US oppose both wars"/><ref name="Associated Press – GfK poll, July 16–20, 2009"/><ref name="Most Americans oppose Afghanistan war: poll"/><ref name="Support for Afghan war drops, CNN poll finds"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Pentagon_Defends_Afghan_Strategy_As_Public_Support_For_War_Ebbs_/1814766.html|title=Pentagon Defends Afghan Strategy As Public Support For War Ebbs|work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref> -->
A Washington Post – ABC poll conducted July 15–18, 2009 found that just half of Americans, 51%, think the war is worth fighting, while nearly half, 45%, think the war is not worth fighting – a statistical tie within the poll's ±3 point margin of error.<ref name="ABC News-Washington Post Poll">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/PollingUnit/story?id=8136983|title=Wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, ABC News Washington Post Poll - ABC News|author=ABC News|work=ABC News|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="U.S. Deaths Hit A Record High in Afghanistan">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/07/21/AR2009072103390.html?hpid=moreheadlines|title=U.S. Deaths Hit A Record High In Afghanistan|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=22 July 2009}}</ref><ref name="Washington Post-ABC News poll July 15–18, 2009">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/polls/postpoll_072009.html|title=Washington Post-ABC News (washingtonpost.com)|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> The American public is also closely divided on whether the United States is making significant progress toward winning the war, with 46% thinking so and 42% not.<ref name="U.S. Deaths Hit A Record High in Afghanistan"/>
An Associated Press – GfK poll conducted July 16–20, 2009 found that the majority 53% of Americans oppose the war, while 44% support it. It furthermore found that the plurality of Americans, 34%, strongly opposed the war, while 20% strongly favored it. (Another 19% somewhat opposed the war, 20% somewhat favored it, and 3% did not know or declined to answer.)<!-- Associated Press – GfK poll, July 16–20 --><ref name="Majority in US oppose both wars">[http://www.miamiherald.com/515/story/1154254.html Majority in US oppose both wars] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref name="Poll details: Majority in US oppose both wars">{{cite web|url=http://www.fresnobee.com/news/national-politics/story/1555220.html?storylink=mirelated |title=Local News - FresnoBee.com |publisher= |accessdate=6 February 2015 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref name="Associated Press – GfK poll, July 16–20, 2009">[http://www.ap-gfkpoll.com/pdf/AP-GfK_Poll_Topline_Politics_Economy_FINAL.pdf Associated Press – GfK poll, July 16–20, 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091211125123/http://www.ap-gfkpoll.com/pdf/AP-GfK_Poll_Topline_Politics_Economy_FINAL.pdf |date=December 11, 2009 }}</ref>
A CNN – Opinion Research poll conducted July 31 – August 3, 2009 also found that most Americans now oppose the war. In a new low in American public support for the war, 54% of Americans said they opposed the war, while 41% supported it.<ref name="Most Americans oppose Afghanistan war: poll">[http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25895398-12335,00.html Most Americans oppose Afghanistan war: poll]</ref><ref name="Support for Afghan war drops, CNN poll finds">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/08/06/poll.afghanistan/|title=Support for Afghan war drops, CNN poll finds|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|date=6 August 2009}}</ref>
Following the [[Afghan presidential election, 2009|August 20, 2009 election]] in Afghanistan that was characterized by widespread lack of security and massive fraud, and capping off the two deadliest months for U.S. troops in the 8-year war, the CNN-Opinion Research poll conducted August 28–31, 2009 registered the highest level of opposition to the war the poll has yet seen. A majority 57% of Americans now oppose the war in Afghanistan, while 42% still support it.<ref name="CNN – Opinion Research poll August 28–31, 2009">[http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnn/2009/images/09/01/rel12a.pdf CNN – Opinion Research poll August 28–31, 2009]</ref><ref name="Losing Afghanistan?">{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/opinion/displaystory.cfm?story_id=14258750|title=The war in Afghanistan: Losing Afghanistan? - The Economist|work=The Economist|accessdate=6 February 2015|date=22 August 2009}}</ref><ref name="West faces losing battle over Afghan poll fraud">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/Afghanistan/article6816479.ece|title=Login|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="CNN Poll: Afghanistan War opposition at all-time high">{{cite news|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/09/01/cnn-poll-afghanistan-war-opposition-at-all-time-high/|title=CNN Poll: Afghanistan War opposition at all-time high|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|date=1 September 2009}}</ref><ref name="August Tied for Deadliest Month in Afghanistan">[http://sbk.online.wsj.com/article/SB125137502095563355.html August Tied for Deadliest Month in Afghanistan]{{dead link|date=August 2015}}</ref>
A Washington Post – ABC News poll conducted September 10–12, 2009 reported that: {{quote|Americans are broadly skeptical of President Obama's contention that the war is necessary for the war against terrorism to be a success, and few see an increase in troops as the right thing to do.}} The poll found that the plurality 42% of Americans now want a reduction of the number of U.S. troops in Afghanistan, and that 26% of Americans think more troops should be sent to Afghanistan.<ref name="A Skeptical View of Afghanistan">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/graphic/2009/09/16/GR2009091600078.html|title=A Skeptical View of Afghanistan|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=16 September 2009}}</ref>
The CNN – Opinion Research poll conducted September 11–13, 2009, found that American opposition to the war reached a new all-time high, while American support for the war fell to a new all-time low. The majority 58% of Americans now oppose the war, while 39% support it.<ref name="Poll: Support for Afghan war at all-time low">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/09/15/afghan.war.poll/#cnnSTCText|title=Poll: Support for Afghan war at all-time low|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=CNN|date=15 September 2009}}</ref>
Keating Holland, CNN's polling director, observed that: {{quote|The Afghan war is almost as unpopular as the Iraq war has been for the past four years.}} He noted that support for the war in Iraq had first dropped to 39 percent in June 2005 then generally remained in the low to mid-30s since.<ref name="Poll: Support for Afghan war at all-time low"/>
The Associated Press – GfK poll conducted October 1–5, 2009 found the majority 57% of Americans oppose the war, up 4% from July, while 40% favor the war, down 4% from July.<ref name="AP-GfK poll conducted October 1–5, 2009">[http://www.ap-gfkpoll.com/pdf/AP-GfK_Poll_First_release%20Topline_10609.pdf AP-GfK poll conducted October 1–5, 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707154339/http://www.ap-gfkpoll.com/pdf/AP-GfK_Poll_First_release%20Topline_10609.pdf |date=July 7, 2011 }}</ref>
The CNN / Opinion Research poll conducted October 30 – November 1, 2009 found that the majority 58% of Americans oppose the war, while 40% support it. The majority 56% of Americans also oppose sending more U.S. troops, while 42% favor doing so.<ref name="Most Americans oppose Afghanistan troop boost: poll">[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jBNWGLn5ijd535wGaC6ojAgd0-fQ Most Americans oppose Afghanistan troop boost: poll] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130131111944/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jBNWGLn5ijd535wGaC6ojAgd0-fQ |date=January 31, 2013 }}</ref>
The Pew Research poll conducted October 28 – November 8, 2009 found that the majority 59% of Americans oppose sending more U.S. troops: The plurality 40% of Americans want the number of U.S. troops to be reduced, and 19% want the number of troops to remain unchanged. 32% support sending more U.S. troops.<ref name="Pew Research poll conducted October 28 – November 8, 2009">{{cite web|url=http://pewresearch.org/pubs/1405/widespread-anti-incumbent-sentiment-obama-approval-afghanistan-troop-levels|title=A Year Out, Widespread Anti-Incumbent Sentiment|date=11 November 2009|work=Pew Research Center for the People and the Press|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
The Gallup poll conducted November 5–8, 2009 found that the majority 51% of Americans oppose sending more U.S. troops: The plurality 44% of Americans want the number of U.S. troops to be reduced, and 7% want the number to be kept unchanged.<ref name="Poll: Majority Opposes New Troops to Afghanistan">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsmax.com/insidecover/afghan_troop_surge/2009/11/13/286058.html |title=Newsmax.com - Breaking news from around the globe: U.S. news, politics, world, health, finance, video, science, technology, live news stream |author=Newsmax |publisher= |accessdate=6 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091116103508/http://www.newsmax.com/insidecover/afghan_troop_surge/2009/11/13/286058.html |archivedate=November 16, 2009 }}</ref><ref name="Withdrawal edges ahead – Poll: Majority opposes new troops">{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/politico44/perm/1109/withdrawal_edges_ahead_7d5fa0bf-cee9-48f2-95d5-9d8e49f0e3c0.html|title=Poll: Majority opposes new troops|author=ALEXANDER BURNS|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="Americans Split on Afghanistan Troop Increase vs. Decrease">{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/124238/Americans-Split-Afghanistan-Troop-Increase-Decrease.aspx?CSTS=alert|title=Americans Split on Afghanistan Troop Increase vs. Decrease|author=Gallup, Inc.|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
The Associated Press – GfK poll conducted November 5–9, 2009 again found that the majority 57% of Americans oppose the war, while 39% favor it.<ref name="Associated Press – GfK poll conducted November 5–9, 2009">[http://www.ap-gfkpoll.com/pdf/AP-GfK_Poll_11_10_09.pdf Associated Press – GfK poll conducted November 5–9, 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091122172004/http://www.ap-gfkpoll.com/pdf/AP-GfK_Poll_11_10_09.pdf |date=November 22, 2009 }}</ref><ref name="Americans grow more pessimistic about direction of country, poll finds">{{cite web|url=http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2009/11/americans_grow_more_pessimisti.html|title=Americans grow more pessimistic about direction of country, poll finds|work=cleveland.com|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
The ABC News / Washington Post poll conducted November 12–15, 2009 found that the majority 52% of Americans now say the war is not worth fighting, a new high in opposition for the poll question first asked in 2007, and that 44% say it is worth fighting, a new low in support. The majority 76% of Americans do not feel that withdrawing would increase the risk of terrorism in the U.S. while 23% feel that it would.<ref name="Majority in US see Afghan war not worth cost: poll">[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hdB3_Jxg-b-jzlCrUcnKg9NYtd_Q Majority in US see Afghan war not worth cost: poll] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091125012113/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hdB3_Jxg-b-jzlCrUcnKg9NYtd_Q |date=November 25, 2009 }}</ref><ref name="ABC News / Washington Post poll conducted November 12–15, 2009">[http://abcnews.go.com/images/PollingUnit/1096a4Afghanistan.pdf ABC News / Washington Post poll conducted November 12–15, 2009]</ref><ref name="Afghan War Support Slips">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/print?id=9105165|title=Poll: Support For Afghan War Slipping|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="While Obama patiently ponders Afghan policy, impatient Americans are already deciding: poll">{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2009/11/obama-afghanistan-poll-sinks.html|title=Top of the Ticket|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=17 November 2009}}</ref>
The CNN / Opinion Research poll conducted December 16–20, 2009 found that the majority 55% of Americans oppose the war, while 43% support it.<ref name="CNN / Opinion Research poll conducted January 22–24, 2010">[http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnn/2010/images/01/27/rel2e.pdf CNN / Opinion Research poll conducted January 22–24, 2010]</ref>
The AP/GfK poll conducted January 12–17, 2010 found that the majority 54% of Americans oppose the war, while 43% support it. The plurality of Americans, 32%, "strongly oppose" the war, while 18% "strongly favor" it. The majority 55% of Americans oppose sending more U.S. troops, while 41% would support doing so. The plurality 34% of Americans "strongly oppose" sending more troops, while 17% "strongly favor" doing so.<ref name="AP/GfK poll conducted January 12–17, 2010">[http://surveys.ap.org/data/GfK/AP-GfK%20Poll%20January%202010%20Topline%20final%2001182010.pdf AP/GfK poll conducted January 12–17, 2010]</ref>
The ABC News / Washington Post poll conducted April 22–25, 2010 showed that the majority 52% of Americans think the war has not been worth fighting, and the plurality 38% of Americans "strongly" think that it has not been worth fighting. 45% of Americans think that the war being carried out has been worth fighting, with 26% of Americans that feel that way strongly.<ref name="On Afghanistan, a negative shift">{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/behind-the-numbers/2010/05/on_afghanistan_a_negative_shif.html|title=Behind the Numbers - On Afghanistan, a negative shift|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=The Washington Post}}</ref>
The CNN / Opinion Research poll conducted May 21–23, 2010 found that the majority 56% of Americans oppose their country's war, while 42% support it.<ref name="CNN poll: Instability in Iraq could hurt support for U.S. withdrawal">{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/3756156/Kiwis-favour-bringing-SAS-home-from-Afghanistan |title=Kiwis favour bringing SAS home from Afghanistan |author=Harvey, Sarah |date=May 31, 2010 |newspaper=[[The Dominion Post (Wellington)|The Dominion Post]] |accessdate=October 4, 2011}}</ref>
The ABC News / Washington Post poll conducted June 3–6, 2010 showed that the majority 53% of Americans think the war has not been worth fighting, and the plurality 41% of Americans "strongly" think that it has not been worth fighting. 44% of Americans think that the war being carried out has been worth fighting, with 26% of Americans that feel that way strongly.<ref name="Public remains unfriendly on Afghanistan">{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/behind-the-numbers/2010/06/public_remains_unfriendly_on_a.html?wprss=behind-the-numbers|title=Behind the Numbers - Public remains unfriendly on Afghanistan|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=The Washington Post}}</ref>
The ABC News / Washington Post poll conducted July 7–11, 2010 found that 76% of Americans want to start withdrawing troops by next summer or sooner: 45% call Obama's plan to start withdrawing troops by next summer "about right", and an additional 31% call for the withdrawal to start even sooner. 18% think the withdrawal should start later. The majority 53% of Americans think the war has not been worth fighting, with the plurality 38% of Americans "strongly" feeling so. The poll reported that support for the war hit a new low in the United States: 43% of Americans think the war has been worth fighting, down sharply since the end of the previous year, and the lowest since the question was asked in February 2007.<ref name="Poll: Most Want Afghanistan Withdrawal Timeline">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20010459-503544.html|title=Poll: Most Want Afghanistan Withdrawal Timeline|date=13 July 2010|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=CBS News}}</ref><ref name="Poll: Approval of Afghan War Slips, But U.S. Uneasy About Taliban Talks">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/print?id=11170795|title=Exclusive: Afghan War Approval Plummets|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
The CBS News poll conducted July 9–12, 2010 found that the majority 58% of Americans want their troops withdrawn from the war within the next one or two years, and 35% were willing to have U.S. troops stay longer than two years from now. One-third, 33%, of Americans think large numbers of U.S. troops should be withdrawn in less than a year, another 23% think that should be done within one or two years, and 2% want an immediate withdrawal. 26% of Americans think U.S. troops should remain for as long as it takes, 7% think they should stay another two to five years, and 2% think they should stay for another five to ten years.<ref name="Poll: Most Want Afghanistan Withdrawal Timeline"/><ref name="CBS News Poll released July 13, 2010, p.8, p.17">{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/34290347/CBS-News-Poll-Pessimism-about-Economy-Low-Marks-for-President-Obama-July-9-12-2010|title=CBS News Poll: Pessimism about Economy, Low Marks for President Obama (July 9-12, 2010)|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
The CNN / Opinion Research poll conducted August 6–10, 2010 showed the American public's opposition to the war at an all-time high. The majority 62% of Americans oppose the war, the highest level since the poll question was asked in 2006, while 37% favored the war, an all-time low.<ref name="Poll: U.S. opposition to Afghan war at all-time high">{{cite news|url=http://afghanistan.blogs.cnn.com/2010/08/17/poll-u-s-opposition-to-afghan-war-at-all-time-high/|title=Poll: U.S. opposition to Afghan war at all-time high|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=CNN|date=17 August 2010}}</ref>
The CNN / Opinion Research poll conducted December 17–19, 2010 again showed the American public's opposition to the war reaching a new all-time high. The majority 63% of Americans oppose the war, the highest level reached since the poll question was asked in 2006, while 35% favored the war, again a new all-time low.<ref name="CNN / Opinion Research poll was conducted December 17–19, 2010">[http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnn/2010/images/12/28/rel17m.pdf CNN / Opinion Research poll was conducted December 17–19, 2010]</ref>
Opposition by the American public to the war also reached an all-time high in polling by ABC News and the Washington Post in December 2010. A record 60% majority of Americans say the war has not been worth fighting, while 34% say it has, a new record low of support of the war. The unpopularity of the war has now reached the levels seen for the war in Iraq. 81% of Americans want the withdrawal of American military forces to begin within a few months – either in the summer of 2011 as pledged by President Obama, or even sooner than that.<ref name="Record Six in 10 Say it's 'Not Worth Fighting'">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/abc-news-washington-post-poll-exclusive-afghanistan-war/story?id=12404367|title=ABC News-Washington Post Poll Exclusive: Afghanistan War Support Drops; Obama's Handling Gets Mixed Reviews - ABC News|author=ABC News|work=ABC News|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="Assessment of Afghanistan War Sours">[http://www.langerresearch.com/uploads/1119a6%20Afghanistan.pdf ABC News/Washington Post Poll: Assessment of Afghanistan War Sours – Record Six in 10 Say it's 'Not Worth Fighting']</ref>
In January 2011, the USA Today / Gallup poll of January 14–16 reported that the majority 72% of Americans want the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan to be accelerated – including majorities in the three political groups – while 25% disagree. Of note, the plurality of Americans, 41%, "strongly" favor speeding up the withdrawal, while 6% "strongly" oppose doing so.<ref name="Poll: 72 Percent Of Americans Want Faster Withdrawal From Afghanistan">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/08/afghanistan-withdrawal-poll-72-percent_n_820341.html|title=Poll: 72 Percent Of Americans Want Faster Withdrawal From Afghanistan|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=6 February 2015|date=8 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="USA Today/Gallup poll January 2011">{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/145880/Alternative-Energy-Bill-Best-Among-Eight-Proposals.aspx|title=In U.S., Alternative Energy Bill Does Best Among Eight Proposals|author=Gallup, Inc.|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="USA Today/Gallup poll January 2011 PDF">[http://www.preview.gallup.com/poll/file/145862/Referendum_110202.pdf USA Today/Gallup poll January 2011 PDF]</ref>
In March 2011, the Washington Post / ABC News poll of March 10–13 reported that the majority 64% of Americans say that the war is no longer worth fighting – the highest level of American opposition to the war measured by the poll – while 31% thought it was – the lowest level of support to date. Nearly three-quarters of Americans, 73%, want President Obama to withdraw a "substanstial number" of troops this summer – while 21% do not. Nearly half of Americans, the plurality 49%, "strongly" think the war is not worth fighting, while 17% strongly think it is.<ref name="Poll: Nearly two-thirds of Americans say Afghan war isn't worth fighting">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/poll-nearly-two-thirds-of-americans-say-afghan-war-isnt-worth-fighting/2011/03/14/ABRbeEW_print.html|title=Poll: Nearly two-thirds of Americans say Afghan war isn't worth fighting|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref name="Washington Post-ABC News Poll, March 10–13, 2011">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/polls/postpoll_03142011.html|title=Washington Post-ABC News Poll|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=The Washington Post}}</ref>
Following the killing of [[Osama bin Laden]], the USA Today / Gallup poll of May 5–8, 2011, reported that the majority 59% of Americans think the U.S. has finished its work and its troops should be brought home. 36% disagreed, and not a single major demographic group had a majority that favored keeping U.S. military forces in Afghanistan.<ref name="Poll: With bin Laden dead, is it time to end war?">[https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-05-10-Afghanistan-mission-bin-Laden-troops-poll_n.htm Poll: With bin Laden dead, is it time to end war?] The USA Today / Gallup poll was conducted May 5–8, 2011.</ref><ref name="Shrouded in secrecy">{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,15051317,00.html|title=Shrouded in secrecy: The elite US unit behind bin Laden′s killing - World - DW.DE - 05.05.2011|work=DW.DE|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="USA Today / Gallup poll May 5–8, 2011">{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/147488/Americans-Positive-Afghanistan-Bin-Laden-Death.aspx|title=Americans More Positive on Afghanistan After Bin Laden Death|author=Gallup, Inc.|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
The Associated Press – GfK poll conducted May 5–9, 2011 reported that the majority 59% of Americans oppose the war, with the plurality 32% of Americans "strongly" opposed to it. 37% of Americans favored the war, the lowest level of support to date. The majority 80% of Americans approve of President Barack Obama's decision to end all U.S. combat operations by 2014 and to begin the withdrawal of troops in July, with the plurality 52% "strongly" approving the ending of combat operations. 15% disapproved, with 8% "strongly" disapproving. The majority 83% of Americans think the announced pace of withdrawal is either about right or too slow, while 15% think it is too fast.<ref name="AP-GfK Poll – May 5th – May 9th Full Topline">[http://www.ap-gfkpoll.com/pdf/AP-GfK%20Poll%20May%20Full%20Topline%20051111.pdf AP-GfK Poll – May 5th – May 9th Full Topline] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722032320/http://www.ap-gfkpoll.com/pdf/AP-GfK%20Poll%20May%20Full%20Topline%20051111.pdf |date=July 22, 2011 }}</ref>
The CBS News / New York Times poll of June 24–28, 2011 reported that the majority 58% of Americans oppose the U.S. military involvement in Afghanistan – the highest level of opposition yet recorded by the poll – while 35% thought the U.S. was doing the "right thing" in fighting its war. 79% of Americans approve of the announced withdrawal of all U.S. troops by the end of 2014, with 59% of Americans wanting even more than one-third of all U.S. troops withdrawn within the next year, by the end of summer 2012. Altogether, 85% of Americans – including the 75% of Republicans – want at least one-third of U.S. troops withdrawn within the next year, by the end of summer 2012.<ref name="Poll: Four in 5 approve of Obama's plan for Afghanistan drawdown">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20075503-503544.html|title=Poll: Four in 5 approve of Obama's plan for Afghanistan drawdown|date=29 June 2011|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=CBS News}}</ref><ref name="CBS News / NYT Poll 2011/06/29">[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/06/29/politics/main20075556.shtml CBS News / NYT Poll 2011/06/29] The New York Times / CBS poll was conducted June 24–28, 2011.</ref>
In January 2013, the Media and Public Opinion Research Group reported that most Americans want the U.S. to pull out of Afghanistan: 37% think the U.S. should withdraw troops gradually, while 30.2% say the U.S. should withdraw immediately.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mpopost.com/most-americans-want-to-leave-afghanistan/ |accessdate=April 22, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515113756/http://www.mpopost.com/most-americans-want-to-leave-afghanistan/ |archivedate=May 15, 2013 }}</ref>
The Pew Research Center poll released at the 10th anniversary of the U.S. invasion reported that the majority 52% of Americans think that, considering the costs versus the benefits to the United States, the war has not been worth fighting, while 41% think it has.<ref name="War and Sacrifice in the Post-9/11 Era">[http://www.pewsocialtrends.org/files/2011/10/war-and-sacrifice-in-the-post-9-11-era.pdf War and Sacrifice in the Post-9/11 Era, p.112.7] The Pew Research Center poll was conducted July 28 – September 15, 2011.</ref>

===Dichotomy between Republicans and Democrats=== A dichotomy between [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] exists as well. The Associated Press – GfK poll conducted July 16–20, 2009 found 66% of Republicans favoring the war, while 26% of Democrats do.<!-- Associated Press – GfK poll, July 16–20 --><ref name="Majority in US oppose both wars"/><ref name="Poll details: Majority in US oppose both wars"/><ref name="Associated Press – GfK poll, July 16–20, 2009"/><ref name="Obama Nears Key Decisions on Afghan Strategy">{{cite web|url=http://www.thenation.com/article/160616/obama-nears-key-decisions-afghan-strategy|title=Obama Nears Key Decisions on Afghan Strategy|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
The CNN – Opinion Research poll conducted July 31 – August 3, 2009 found that nearly two-thirds of Republicans support the war, while three quarters of Democrats oppose the war. CNN polling director Keating Holland said:<ref name="Most Americans oppose Afghanistan war: poll"/><ref name="Support for Afghan war drops, CNN poll finds"/>
{{quote|Afghanistan is almost certainly the Obama policy that Republicans like the most.}}
An ABC News-Washington Post poll conducted August 13–17, 2009 found that 78% of conservative Republicans think the war is worth fighting, while 22% of liberal Democrats do. 65% of conservative Republicans also think that the U.S. is winning the war. 64% of liberal Democrats want the number of U.S. troopsto be reduced, while 22% of conservative Republicans do.<ref name="ABC News – Washington Post poll August 13–17, 2009">[http://abcnews.go.com/images/PollingUnit/1093a2Afghanistan.pdf ABC News – Washington Post poll August 13–17, 2009]</ref>
A McClatchy-Ipsos poll conducted August 27–31, 2009, reported that 66% of Democrats and 67% of independents oppose sending more U.S. troops. In one group was there a majority in favor of sending more troops, with 52% of Republicans favoring a further escalation.<ref name="Poll: Most say Afghanistan war not worth fighting">[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jk484sNjuk4UClkriVsiCFd_s2hAD9A68T880 Poll: Most say Afghanistan war not worth fighting] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
The CNN – Opinion Research poll conducted August 28–31, 2009 again showed that most of the support for the war is from Republicans. Seven in ten Republicans support the war, while nearly three quarters of Democrats oppose the war, as do 57% of independents.<ref name="CNN – Opinion Research poll August 28–31, 2009"/><ref name="CNN Poll: Afghanistan War opposition at all-time high"/>
The Washington Post – ABC News poll conducted September 10–12, 2009 found that the majority 56% of Democrats want a reduction of the number of U.S. troops, while the plurality 39% of Republicans want more troops to be sent to the war. 17% of Democrats support sending more troops. The poll also reported that the majority 59% of Democrats think the "war on terrorism" can be a success without winning, while the majority 66% of Republicans think the war must be won to win the "war on terrorism".<ref name="A Skeptical View of Afghanistan"/><ref name="Anti-War Stirrings Greet Call For More Troops">{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/behind-the-numbers/2009/09/anti-war_stirrings_greet_call.html|title=Behind the Numbers - Anti-War Stirrings Greet Call For More Troops|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=The Washington Post}}</ref>
The CNN – Opinion Research poll conducted September 11–13, 2009 found that 23% of Democrats and 39% independents support the war, while a majority 62% of Republicans support the war. The majority 75% of Democrats oppose the war.<ref name="Poll: Support for Afghan war at all-time low"/><ref name="Amy Goodman: U.S. must not become the evil it deplores">[http://www.auburnpub.com/articles/2009/09/19/opinion/amy_goodman.txt Amy Goodman: U.S. must not become the evil it deplores]</ref>
The USA Today – Gallup poll conducted September 22–23, 2009 found that the majority 62% of Democrats oppose sending more U.S. troops, while the majority 63% of Republicans favor sending more U.S. troops. The majority 53% of Democrats want to begin a withdrawal of U.S. troops, while 24% of Republicans want a withdrawal to begin. 30% of Democrats support sending more U.S. troops. Nearly half, 49% of independents oppose sending more U.S. troops, and the plurality 43% of independents also want to begin to withdraw U.S. troops from Afghanistan.<ref name="Poll: 50% oppose U.S. surge in Afghanistan">{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2009-09-25-afghanistan_N.htm|title=Poll: 50% oppose U.S. surge in Afghanistan - USATODAY.com|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=USA Today|first=Ken|last=Dilanian|date=25 September 2009}}</ref>
The Pew Research Center poll conducted September 10–15, 2009 found that 56% of Democrats want to remove NATO troops "as soon as possible", while, in contrast, 71% of Republicans favor keeping them. By nearly two to one, 55% to 29%, Republicans also thought the U.S. is making progress rather than losing ground in defeating the Taliban militarily. Among Democrats and independents 46% and 49%, respectively, said the U.S. is losing ground in defeating the Taliban militarily.<ref name="Foreign and Domestic Polls Show Declining Support for U.S. Engagement Abroad">{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/blogs/jodie-allen/2009/09/30/foreign-and-domestic-polls-show-declining-support-for-us-engagement-abroad.html|title=Foreign and Domestic Polls Show Declining Support for U.S. Engagement Abroad|author=Jodie Allen|authorlink=Jodie Allen|work=US News & World Report|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="Public Support for Afghanistan War Wanes">{{cite web|url=http://pewresearch.org/pubs/1349/support-falls-afghanistan-war-troop-removal|title=Public Support for Afghan Mission Slips|date=22 September 2009|work=Pew Research Center for the People and the Press|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="Pew Research Center September 10–15, 2009 poll topline">[http://people-press.org/reports/questionnaires/546.pdf Pew Research Center September 10–15, 2009 poll topline]</ref>
The Associated Press – GfK poll conducted October 1–5, 2009 found that the majority 57% of Democrats oppose sending more troops, while, on the other hand, the majority 69% of Republicans favor sending more troops there.<ref name="Obama ponders Afghanistan troop boost">{{cite news|url=http://news.theage.com.au/breaking-news-world/obama-ponders-afghanistan-troop-boost-20091007-gmgu.html|title=Obama ponders Afghanistan troop boost|work=The Age|accessdate=6 February 2015|location=Melbourne}}</ref>
The Clarus Research poll conducted October 1–4, 2009, found that 17% of Democrats supported sending more troops. The majority 61% of Democrats want to "decrease U.S. troop numbers in Afghanistan and begin to get out". The majority 54% of Republicans favor sending more U.S. troops. Ron Faucheux, president of Clarus Research Group, said:<ref name="Democrats Strongly Oppose Sending More Troops to Afghanistan, Most Voters Wary of War's Outcome">{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/democrats-strongly-oppose-sending-more-troops-to-afghanistan-most-voters-wary-of-wars-outcome-63556702.html|title=Democrats Strongly Oppose Sending More Troops to Afghanistan, Most Voters Wary of War's Outcome|author=Clarus Research Group|date=5 October 2009|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
{{quote|Should President Obama decide to send more troops to Afghanistan, he will do it in the face of strong opposition from voters in his own party.}}
In a USA Today / Gallup poll conducted October 6, 2009, 59% of Democrats, and 50% of independents, opposed sending more troops, while 73% of Republicans favored sending more troops. Half, 50%, of Democrats wanted President Obama to begin to withdraw U.S. troops, while 18% of Republicans wanted this.<ref name="Americans Divided on Sending More Troops to Afghanistan">{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/123521/Americans-Divided-Sending-Troops-Afghanistan.aspx|title=Americans Divided on Sending More Troops to Afghanistan|author=Gallup, Inc.|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
In the CBS News poll conducted October 5–8, 2009, the majority 52% of Democrats wanted to decrease the number of U.S. troops, while the majority 57% of Republicans wanted to increase the number of U.S. troops. 27% of Democrats support sending more troops. The majority 76% of Republicans think the U.S. is doing the right thing by fighting the war, while, on the other hand, the plurality 49% of Democrats think the U.S. should not be involved.<ref name="CBS News poll conducted October 5–8, 2009">[http://www.cbsnews.com/htdocs/pdf/poll_afghanistan_100909.pdf CBS News poll conducted October 5–8, 2009]</ref>
In the ABC News – Washington Post poll conducted October 15–18, 2009, the majority 60% of Democrats opposed sending more U.S. troops, while the majority 69% of Republicans favored sending more troops. 36% of Democrats felt the war was worth fighting, while 71% of Republicans did.<ref name="ABC News poll conducted October 5–8, 2009">[http://abcnews.go.com/images/PollingUnit/1095a3Afghanistan.pdf ABC News poll conducted October 15–18, 2009]</ref><ref name="Obama's Ratings Slip on Afghanistan">{{cite web|url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/PollingUnit/Politics/afghanistan-abc-news-washington-post-poll/Story?id=8872471&page=2|title=Page 2: Afghanistan, ABC News Washington Post Poll - ABC News|author=ABC News|work=ABC News|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="Americans divided on Afghan troop increase">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/10/21/AR2009102100173_pf.html Americans divided on Afghan troop increase]{{dead link|date=August 2015}}</ref>
In the Pew Research poll conducted October 28 – November 8, 2009, the majority 70% of Democrats oppose sending more U.S. troops, while 48% of Republicans favor sending more troops there. The plurality 50% of Democrats want the number of U.S. troops in Afghanistan to be reduced, while 25% of Republicans did as well.<ref name="Pew Research poll conducted October 28 – November 8, 2009"/>
In the Gallup poll conducted November 5–8, 2009, the majority 66% of Democrats oppose sending more U.S. troops, while 63% of Republicans want to send more troops. The majority 60% of Democrats want President Obama to, in fact, begin reducing U.S. troop levels. 26% of Republicans wanted a reduction in troops to begin. Gallup noted:<ref name="Poll: Majority Opposes New Troops to Afghanistan"/><ref name="Withdrawal edges ahead – Poll: Majority opposes new troops"/><ref name="Americans Split on Afghanistan Troop Increase vs. Decrease"/>
In the ABC News / Washington Post poll conducted November 12–15, 2009, the political divide in the U.S. over the war continued: the majority 66% of Democrats say the war is not worth fighting, with nearly half of Democrats, 48%, feeling strongly that the war is not worth fighting, while, on the other hand, the majority 60% of Republicans say that it is worth fighting, with 43% of Republicans feeling strongly that it is.<ref name="Partisan divide widens as Obama considers Afghanistan policy">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/11/21/AR2009112101240_pf.html|title=Sunday Take: Divided public complicates Afghanistan decision|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=The Washington Post|first=Dan|last=Balz}}</ref>
The CNN / Opinion Research poll conducted May 21–23, 2010 noted that the war remained popular with Republicans, with a majority two-thirds of them favoring continuation of the war. 27% of Democrats supported the war, and among independents support has fallen to 40%.<ref name="CNN poll: Instability in Iraq could hurt support for U.S. withdrawal"/>
The Pew Global Attitudes survey released in June 2010 also noted the significant partisan difference, finding that nearly two-thirds, a 65% majority, of Republicans wanted to continue to keep the military forces in Afghanistan indefinitely, while 36% of Democrats supported this.<ref name="Pew2010"/>
The ABC News / Washington Post poll conducted June 3–6, 2010 similarly reported that the majority 62% of Republicans think the almost-nine-year war imposed on that country has been worth its costs to the U.S., while the majority two-thirds, 66%, of Democrats and 53% of independents think it has not been worth fighting. In fact, the majority 54% of Democratic-leaning Americans "strongly" think that the war has not been worth fighting.<ref name="Public remains unfriendly on Afghanistan"/>
The CBS News poll conducted July 9–12, 2010 also reported the strong partisan divide over the war. The 73% majority of Democrats want a timetable set for withdrawal, while the majority 66% of Republicans do not. The nearly-three-quarters majority, 74%, of Democrats want most U.S. troops to be withdrawn within a year or two, while a majority 52% of Republicans want them to stay longer than another two years.<ref name="Poll: Most Want Afghanistan Withdrawal Timeline"/><ref name="CBS News Poll released July 13, 2010, p.8, p.17"/>
The CNN / Opinion Research poll conducted October 5–7, 2010 reported that 68% of Democrats oppose the war, while, on the other hand, the majority 51% of Republicans favor the war, the only group of respondents to do so. 28% of Democrats support the war. Among Independents, the majority 61% oppose the war, while 35% support it.<ref name="CNN / Opinion Research poll October 5–7, 2010">[http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnn/2010/images/10/14/rel14f.pdf CNN/Opinion Research poll October 5–7, 2010]</ref>
The ABC News / Washington Post poll conducted December 9–12, 2010 continued to find that Republicans remained the most supportive of warfare in Afghanistan: albeit down 35% from the peak in 2007, 50% of Republicans still say the war has been worth fighting in that country. Among Democrats 36% think the war has been worth fighting.<ref name="Record Six in 10 Say it's 'Not Worth Fighting'"/><ref name="Assessment of Afghanistan War Sours"/>
In the CNN / Opinion Research poll conducted December 17–19, 2010, the three-quarters majority of Democratic voters oppose the war, as do more than six in ten independent voters, while, on the other hand, 52% of Republicans, and 52% of Tea Party supporters, supported continuation of the war.<ref name="CNN / Opinion Research poll was conducted December 17–19, 2010"/>
The Washington Post / ABC News poll conducted March 10–13, 2011 reported that 19% of Democratic voters think the war is worth fighting – compared to half of Republican supporters, the chief constituency supporting the war. The majority two-thirds of independent voters think the war is not worth fighting, while about one-in-four think it is. 80% of independent voters want Barack Obama to withdraw a "substantial number" of troops from Afghanistan "this summer".<ref name="Poll: Nearly two-thirds of Americans say Afghan war isn't worth fighting"/><ref name="Washington Post-ABC News Poll, March 10–13, 2011"/>
In the USA Today / Gallup poll conducted May 5–8, 2011, a week following the killing of [[Osama bin Laden]], Democratic and independent voters, by a 2-to-1 margin, believe the U.S. has finished its work and should now bring its troops home. The majority two-thirds of Democratic voters, 66%, think that U.S. troops should now be brought home, as do the majority 62% of independent voters. Among Republican voters, an equal number, 47%, think that the American troops should be brought home, and 47% do not. Not a single major demographic group had a majority that favored keeping U.S. military forces in Afghanistan.<ref name="Poll: With bin Laden dead, is it time to end war?"/><ref name="Shrouded in secrecy"/><ref name="USA Today / Gallup poll May 5–8, 2011"/>
In the Gallup poll conducted June 25–26, 2011, the majority of Democratic and independent voters favor the announced withdrawal of all U.S. troops by 2014. 87% of Democratic voters and 74% of independent voters favor the planned withdrawal, with 11% and 21% opposed. 50% of Republican voters also favor the announced withdrawal, while 43% opposed it. In the same poll 54% of Republicans thought a timetable should not be set.<ref name="Broadly Favor Obama's Afghanistan Pullout Plan – Fewer than half agree with specific troop reduction goals">{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/148313/Americans-Broadly-Favor-Obama-Afghanistan-Pullout-Plan.aspx|title=Americans Broadly Favor Obama's Afghanistan Pullout Plan|author=Gallup, Inc.|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
In the CBS News / New York Times poll conducted June 24–28, 2011, the majority 60% of Democratic voters and 63% of independent voters oppose their country's military involvement, while 32% and 28%, respectively, support it. 90% of Democratic voters and 79% of independent voters approved of the plan to withdraw all U.S. troops by the end of 2014. 94% of Democratic voters and 84% of independent voters want at least one-third of U.S. troops withdrawn within a year, by the end of summer 2012. On the other hand, Republican voters were split, with 48% opposed to the U.S. military involvement and 47% supporting it. 67% of Republican voters approve of President Obama's plan to withdraw all U.S. troops by the end of 2014, and 75% want at least one-third of the trooops withdrawn within a year, by the end of summer 2012.<ref name="Poll: Four in 5 approve of Obama's plan for Afghanistan drawdown"/><ref name="CBS News / NYT Poll 2011/06/29"/>
In the Pew Research Center poll released at the 10th anniversary of the U.S. invasion of Afghanistan and the longest period of sustained warfare in its history, the majority 59% of Democratic voters and the majority 58% of independent voters think the war has not been worth fighting, while 34% and 36%, respectively, think it has. On the other hand, the majority 56% of Republicans think the decade-long war has been worth fighting, while 37% think it has not.<ref name="War and Sacrifice in the Post-9/11 Era"/>
===Increasing opposition to the war among conservatives=== In a January 2011 poll of conservatives, 66% of self-identified conservative voters and [[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] supporters call for either a reduction of U.S. troop levels (the 39% plurality) or a complete withdrawal "as soon as possible" (27%). 24% think that the current levels of troops should be maintained. The majority 71% of conservative voters, including over two-thirds of Tea Party supporters, are worried that the war's cost to American taxpayers – $120 billion spent on the war in 2010 – will make it more difficult to reduce the U.S. deficit next year and balance the U.S. federal budget in the next decade. The poll for the Afghanistan Study Group was conducted January 4–10, 2011.<ref name="Tea Party eyes the cost of war in Afghanistan">{{cite web|url=http://www.caivn.org/article/2011/01/15/tea-party-eyes-cost-war-afghanistan|title=Tea Party eyes the cost of war in Afghanistan|work=IVN.us|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="Afghanistan Study Group – Survey Results of Conservatives">{{cite web|url=http://www.afghanistanstudygroup.org/2011/01/12/afghanistan-study-group-survey-results-of-conservatives/|title=Afghanistan Study Group – Survey Results of Conservatives|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
A USA Today / Gallup poll conducted January 14–16, 2011 also reported that, behind an 86% of Democrats and 72% of independents, there was now also 61% of self-identified conservatives calling for an accelerated withdrawal of U.S. troops.<ref name="Poll: 72 Percent Of Americans Want Faster Withdrawal From Afghanistan"/><ref name="USA Today/Gallup poll January 2011"/><ref name="USA Today/Gallup poll January 2011 PDF"/>
In the Gallup poll conducted June 25–26, 2011, 50% of Republican voters generally favor the announced withdrawal of all U.S. troops from Afghanistan by 2014, while 43% opposed it.<ref name="Broadly Favor Obama's Afghanistan Pullout Plan – Fewer than half agree with specific troop reduction goals"/>
In the CBS News / New York Times poll conducted June 24–28, 2011, 67% of Republican voters approve of the plan to withdraw all U.S. troops by the end of summer 2012, and 75% of Republican voters want at least one-third of U.S. troops withdrawn by the end of summer 2012: the plurality 41% of Republican voters want more than one-third of U.S. troops withdrawn in this timeframe, 34% want about a third, while 18% thought it should be less than one-third.<ref name="Poll: Four in 5 approve of Obama's plan for Afghanistan drawdown"/><ref name="CBS News / NYT Poll 2011/06/29"/>
==Opinions of the public in NATO allies of the U.S.== {{See also|Opposition to the War in Afghanistan (2001–present)}}
===2008=== In 2008, not one of the six NATO allies in the Pew Global Attitudes survey had majority support for keeping troops in Afghanistan, and five of the six had majorities wanting withdrawal as soon as possible. In 2009, not one of the seven NATO allies in the Pew Global Attitudes survey had majority support for continuing to keep military forces there, but all seven of the NATO allies in the survey had majority or strong plurality opposition to sending more troops.<ref name="24-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Project Survey"/><ref name="24-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Project Survey"/><ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.22 Opposition to War in Afghanistan"/><ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.39 (PDF p.43)"/>
===2009=== The June 2009 "Transatlantic Trends" survey of 13 NATO countries, also from an American policy think tank, the [[German Marshall Fund of the United States]], further underlined the publics' opposition to the war in NATO countries involved with the U.S. in Afghanistan.<ref name="German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends survey 2009 – Key Findings p.4–5, p.14–15">{{cite web|url=http://www.gmfus.org/trends/2009/docs/2009_English_Key.pdf |title=German Marshall Fund of the United States |publisher= |accessdate=6 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091009105615/http://www.gmfus.org/trends/2009/docs/2009_English_Key.pdf |archivedate=October 9, 2009 }}</ref><ref name="German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends survey 2009 – Topline Data p.34">{{cite web|url=http://www.gmfus.org/trends/2009/docs/2009_English_Top.pdf |title=German Marshall Fund of the United States |publisher= |accessdate=6 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090920030448/http://www.gmfus.org/trends/2009/docs/2009_English_Top.pdf |archivedate=September 20, 2009 }}</ref>
The majorities of the populations of all 12 of the NATO nations surveyed in Europe and Turkey want their military forces in Afghanistan to be reduced or completely withdrawn – United Kingdom (60%), France (51%), Germany (57%), Italy (55%), Netherlands (50%), Poland (68%), Portugal (52%), Spain (54%), Slovakia (61%), Bulgaria (72%), Romania (61%), Turkey (50%).<ref name="German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends survey 2009 – Key Findings p.4–5, p.14–15"/><ref name="German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends survey 2009 – Topline Data p.34"/>
The majority 55% of West Europeans and the majority 69% of East Europeans want to reduce or remove their troops from Afghanistan, with complete troop removal called for by 51% of Poles, 50% of Bulgarians, 48% of Romanians, 41% of Britons, and 41% of Germans.<ref name="German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends survey 2009 – Key Findings p.4–5, p.14–15"/>
Despite pressure from the Obama administration to increase their troop levels in Afghanistan, the public is strongly opposed in all 12 of the NATO ally countries surveyed. 77% of people, in the 12 NATO countries surveyed in the Europe Union and Turkey oppose sending more troops to Afghanistan. Fewer than 1 in 5 people, 19%, in the 12 NATO countries supported sending more troops.<ref name="German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends survey 2009 – Key Findings p.4–5, p.14–15"/>
{| class="wikitable" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" style="background:white; text-align:center; font-size:85%;" |+ Level of support for sending more troops to Afghanistan | style="background:#eee" | ''NATO member'' || style="background:#eee; width:30px;"| ''% Support 2009'' || style="background:#eee; width:30px;"| % ''Support 2010'' || style="background:#eee; width:30px;"| % ''Support 2011'' |- | style="text-align:left" | United States || 30% || 25% || 6% |- | style="text-align:left" | United Kingdom || 11% || 7% || 3% |- | style="text-align:left" | France || 4% || 4% || 2% |- | style="text-align:left" | Germany || 7% || 7% || 4% |- | style="text-align:left" | Italy || 6% || 4% || 2% |- | style="text-align:left" | Netherlands || 4% || 4% || 5% |- | style="text-align:left" | Poland || 5% || 2% || 2% |- | style="text-align:left" | Portugal || 4% || 2% || 3% |- | style="text-align:left" | Spain || 7% || 6% || 3% |- | style="text-align:left" | Slovakia || 2% || 3% || 2% |- | style="text-align:left" | Bulgaria || 2% || 2% || 1% |- | style="text-align:left" | Romania || 5% || 6% || 2% |- | style="text-align:left" | Turkey || 14% || 16% || 12% |} ''(Source: German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends June 2009, 2010, and 2011 surveys<ref name="German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends survey 2009 – Topline Data p.34"/><ref name="German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends survey 2010 – Topline Data p.39–42">{{cite web|url=http://www.gmfus.org/trends/doc/2010_English_Top.pdf |title=German Marshall Fund of the United States |publisher= |accessdate=6 February 2015 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>)''
The poll of the NATO countries, conducted in June 2009, about 2 months before the [[Afghan presidential election, 2009|Afghan election]], also reported that 56% of Americans were optimistic about stabilizing the situation in Afghanistan, whereas the majority 62% of people in the 12 NATO countries in Europe and Turkey were not.<ref name="German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends survey 2009 – Key Findings p.4–5, p.14–15"/>
In the 2009 Pew Global Attitudes Project survey, none of the seven NATO allies surveyed had majority support for keeping NATO troops in Afghanistan. Despite repeated American calls for their NATO allies to send more troops to Afghanistan, there was majority or plurality opposition to such action in all seven of the NATO ally countries surveyed: Germany (63% disapprove), France (62%), Poland (57%), Canada (55%), Britain (51%), Spain (50%), and Turkey (49%).<ref name="25-Nation Pew Global Attitudes Survey, 2009, p.39 (PDF p.43)"/>
===2010=== In 2010, none of the six NATO allies in the Pew Global Attitudes survey had majority support for keeping troops in Afghanistan. The survey found instead that the majorities and pluralities of the public in 5 out of 6 NATO member countries want the NATO military forces to be removed from Afghanistan "as soon as possible". A 67% majority in Turkey, 58% majority in Germany, 52% majority in France, 49% plurality in Spain, 44% plurality in Poland, and 45% in the United Kingdom all want the NATO military forces to be removed from Afghanistan "as soon as possible".<ref name="Pew2010"/>
The Transatlantic Trends June 2010 study by the German Marshall Fund of the United States found that pluralities all of the 12 NATO ally countries surveyed, and majorities in 11 out of 12 of them, want to withdraw all or some of their troops from Afghanistan.<ref name="German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends survey 2010 – Topline Data p.39–42"/><ref name="Only Americans remain upbeat about Afghanistan: poll">{{cite web|url=http://www.expatica.com/de/news/german-news/only-americans-remain-upbeat-about-afghanistan-poll_96510.html|title=Only Americans remain upbeat about Afghanistan: poll|publisher=|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
For the 12 European NATO countries surveyed as a whole, 70% think their country should begin to withdraw troops immediately (36%) or in 2011 if conditions permit (36%). 23% think their troops should stay as long as it takes to "stabilize" Afghanistan. The majority 62% of the European NATO populations surveyed want a complete withdrawal of all of their troops (the 43% plurality) or a reduction of troops (19%). 28% would keep the troop numbers at their current levels. 6% would agree to send more troops to Afghanistan.<ref name="German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends survey 2010 – Topline Data p.39–42"/><ref name="Only Americans remain upbeat about Afghanistan: poll"/>
===2011=== The Transatlantic Trends June 2011 study by the German Marshall Fund of the United States found that majorities in the United States (66%) and in all 11 European NATO member countries surveyed – the United Kingdom (69%), Germany (70%), France (64%), Italy (65%), Poland (73%), Portugal (58%), Spain (57%), Netherlands (55%), Romania (67%), Bulgaria (63%), and Slovakia (64%) – want all or some troops withdrawn from Afghanistan. For all 11 European NATO countries taken as a whole, the majority 66% of Europeans in the NATO countries surveyed want all or some of their troops withdrawn from Afghanistan: the plurality 44% want all of their troops to be withdrawn from Afghanistan, another 22% want some of their troops to be withdrawn to reduce the number there. Less than one in three, 29%, support maintaining the current number of troops in Afghanistan, and 3% would support sending yet more troops.<ref name="German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends 2011">[http://www.gmfus.org/publications_/TT/TTS2011Toplines.pdf German Marshall Fund of the United States – Transatlantic Trends 2011] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120604224817/http://www.gmfus.org/publications_/TT/TTS2011Toplines.pdf |date=June 4, 2012 }}</ref>
In December 2010, the U.S. Secretary of Defense, [[Robert Gates]], acknowledged the opposition of the public in almost all countries: {{quote|Public opinion would be … in terms of majority, against their participation [in the war].<ref name="Afghan war not worth it, say most Americans"/>}}
===2014===
[[Marek Obrtel]], former [[Podpolkovnik|Lieutenant Colonel]] in Field Hospital with [[Military of the Czech Republic|Czech Republic army]], returned his medals which he received during his posting in [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan War]] for [[NATO]] operations. He criticized the [[War on Terror]] as describing the mission as "deeply ashamed that I served a criminal organization such as NATO, led by the USA and its perverse interests around the world."<ref name="Parlamentni listy">{{cite news|title=Marek Obrtel: Hluboce se stydím za zločineckou organizaci, jakou je NATO. Vracím vyznamenání|url=http://www.parlamentnilisty.cz/arena/nazory-a-petice/Marek-Obrtel-Hluboce-se-stydim-za-zlocineckou-organizaci-jakou-je-NATO-Vracim-vyznamenani-351287|accessdate=9 January 2015|work=Parlamentni listy|agency=OUR MEDIA a.s.|issue=22 December 2014|publisher=Parlamentni listy|date=22 December 2014|ref=OUR MEDIA a.s.}}</ref><ref name=Stalo-se>{{cite news|title=Marek Obrtel vrátil vyznamenání, jelikož se stydí za své působení v silách NATO|url=http://www.stalo-se.cz/?p=23082|accessdate=9 January 2015|work=Stalo-se|agency=Stalo-se|issue=26 December 2014|publisher=Stalo-se|date=26 December 2014}}</ref><ref name=Kurzy>{{cite news|last1=stas|title=Cháá je to borec že cháá Pplk. v.z. MUDr. Marek Obrtel : Hluboce se stydím za zločineckou organizaci jakou je NATO. Vracím vyznamenání - Akcie ERSTE BANK|url=http://www.kurzy.cz/akcie-cr/nazory/A-P-T-2048-PR-1162750/|accessdate=9 January 2015|work=Kurzy.cz|issue=25 December 2014|publisher=Kurzy.cz|date=25 December 2014}}</ref>
